entry.title: EWM-TM Integration: Clean Core alternative to unreleased BAdI in S/4HANA PCE
entry.content:
Hey community,

I'm implementing EWM with TM in S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition and hitting a Clean Core compliance issue.

Scenario: When TM is active in the system and I try to process goods issue in EWM (transaction /SCWM/PRDO), I get this error:

/SCWM/LK202 ‚Äì TU for delivery assignment &1 / &2 not found

This happens because when TM is configured, the system automatically sets TRANSPL_TYPE = 'C' (when TMS_PLAN_IND = 'X'), which means EWM expects a Transportation Unit before allowing the goods issue. This blocks the entire outbound process.

Standard solution (blocked in PCE)
Note 3084918 addresses this - implement BAdI /SCWM/EX_ERP_MAPIN_OD_SAVEREPL and in method MAPIN, clear the field TRANSPL_TYPE in structure MT_DLV_REQUEST-s_head-t_transport.

The logic is simple and it works perfectly in on-premise systems. But here's the problem: in S/4HANA PCE with ABAP Cloud, the ATC check fails:

Error: Usage of not released application API: /SCWM/IF_EX_MAPIN_OD_SAVEREPL
Code: CHKC_IFACE_NOT_RELEASED

Can't transport this to production as it violates Clean Core principles.

What I've Tried
Looked for alternative BAdIs that might have access to TRANSPL_TYPE - no luck
Checked if there's any customizing to prevent the default 'C' value - nothing found
Searched for released APIs in the same process - all the relevant ones are unreleased
Tried to find workarounds in /SCWM/TU (called internally by /SCWM/PRDO) - same restrictions

Questions for the Community
Is there a released BAdI or API that allows modifying TRANSPL_TYPE in this EWM-TM scenario?
Any configuration trick to prevent the system from defaulting to transport type 'C' when TM is active?
Has anyone solved this in a Clean Core compliant way? Maybe a different approach I'm not seeing?
Does SAP have plans to release this BAdI for cloud environments? It seems like a standard requirement for EWM-TM integration.
This is becoming a blocker for the go-live. The functionality works great with the BAdI, but I need a solution that passes ATC checks.

Will definitely post the solution here once I find it. Thanks in advance!

Technical Details:

S/4HANA PCE 2023
Transaction: /SCWM/PRDO (Outbound Delivery Order)
Error occurs during goods issue processing
ABAP Cloud with strict ATC enforcement

entry.title: Re: Showing wrong attachment document in SAP MM
entry.content:
Hi @pratik_soni6 

Thank you for raising this issue. I will walk you through it.

Reading your explanation, it describes a common issue often faced while trying to attach mismatched files. Please be aware that the problem you described is typically caused by issues such as attachment file naming, mapping logic in the integration layer, or configuration in Ariba which then affects how attachments are linked to created Purchase Orders.

SAP recommends that you do the following:

First, ensure every Purchase Order attachment has a unique, clearly defined filename. This must be without blank spaces or restricted characters and must not exceed 50 characters in its length.

Then, confirm that the parameters to export attachments or comments to SAP ERP are enabled in your Ariba system.

Please ensure to review and correct your integration or middleware mapping rules to guarantee the actual file sent from Ariba is the one linked and stored against the Purchase Order in SAP.

Finally, ensure to test the process by uploading uniquely named documents and verify if the linkage is correct.

Should the issue persist, I would advice to escalate to SAP support for deeper payload and mapping troubleshooting.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: Preferential origin not determined on invoice
entry.content:
Hi @Pranjal09689p97 

Hi

Reviewing the details you provided on the issue with invoice 99148879 for material ABC, where the preferential origin is showing as ‚ÄúNo‚Äù despite shipment from plant 1001 and production in plant 1004, here are a few considerations I suggest to help you better understand the situation and a possible positive outcome

Potential root cause of the issue:

It is important to note that in SAP ECC, preferential origin confirmation depends on a few factors such as the plant, your master data settings, BOM, supplier declarations, and your defined threshold rules in the shipping plant.

Even if the production plant meets the defined threshold requirement, the origin status may not be transferred or confirmed in the shipping plant unless relevant master data, preference calculation, and cross-plant data transfer are correctly set up.

If the defined preference is correctly determined in the master data but still displays incorrectly, the invoice output program or the form logic may not be pulling the right field.

I would recommend you take these steps:

  • First, ensure to verify material master Foreign Trade or Export Data for both plants 1001 and 1004. This ensures that origin and preference indicators are populated.
  • Then ensure BOM and supplier declarations are complete and transferred to the shipping plant in the cross-plant scenarios.
  • Make sure to check your defined preference determination configuration so that origin status from 1004 is recognized and applied when shipping from 1001.
  • Thereafter, make sure to confirm threshold comparison logic is using data from the correct plant.
  • Finally, if determination is correct but invoice still shows ‚ÄúNo,‚Äù debug the invoice output form or program to ensure preferential origin is read from the correct source.

The issue here is likely master data or configuration in preference determination, not just purely related to the invoice output. If standard logic does not support this cross-plant scenario, an enhancement or BAdI implementation may be required to help you solve the issue.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

 

Preference Statements

Preference Determination

entry.title: Re: SAP IBP object imported into Q or P tenant - how do I...
entry.content:
Hi @contovhal 

Thank you for your question.

The simple answer is no. However, there are a few things to note.

In the current standard SAP IBP, there is no ‚ÄúCreated On‚Äù or ‚ÄúImported On‚Äù date field for business roles or similar objects. The system only shows the Changed On date. This reflects the last modification, not the initial import or creation time.

If a role is not part of any software collection, there is unfortunately no standard way to find out when it was first imported into the tenant. The system does not provide an audit history or log for initial creation in the standard UI or reporting features.

Here are potential workarounds for your use case:

  • First, make use of external governance or identity management tools. e.g., SAP Identity Governance to track creation events if integrated.
  • Then, maintain manual logs when importing or creating new roles in the tenant for the required future reference.

To summarize, the information you are looking for isn‚Äôt available directly in IBP, and tracking must be done via external tools or manual processes in the future.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

 

How to Create Leading and Derived Business Roles

How to Create a User in SAP IBP

entry.title: Re: Fiori App 1704 run outbound process - missing details
entry.content:
Hi @Dirk_Kaestingschaefer 

Thank you for your question. I will walk you through it.

To see the block reason for blocked outbound deliveries in the details screen of the Run Outbound Process app, here are a few considerations and facts.

It is important to note that by default, the block reason (delivery block code) is maintained in SAP ERP/S4 and it controls blocking at delivery header or item level. However, be aware that standard outbound delivery apps which includes those in IBP or warehouse execution do not always display the block reason field in their User Interface with the out-of-the-box solution.

For the required information to be shown, here a few facts that must be in place:

  • The underlying data source which can be the CDS view or OData service used by the outbound delivery details UI must include the delivery block reason field.
  • If those are not present, a backend CDS view or UI extension is needed to expose and display this field.
  • SAP provides standard CDS views for delivery block reasons that can be leveraged for such UI enhancements.

I recommend coordinating with your SAP technical team or UI developers to extend the outbound delivery details screen and include delivery block and block reason information for full visibility.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

 

Sales Order Outbound Delivery Scenario

Delivery-Based Transportation Requirement

entry.title: Re: EWM-TM Integration: Clean Core alternative to unrelea...
entry.content:
Hi @wguedex 

Based on the information you provided regarding your query on the Clean Core compliance issue during EWM‚ÄìTM integration in S/4HANA Private Cloud Edition (PCE), there are a few things to highlight. I will provide a summary of the described situation and guidance on potential next steps:

Here are a few SAP Clean Core compliant confirmed Facts

There is no released BAdI or API currently existing in PCE to modify TRANSPL_TYPE during this process without you violating the defined Clean Core rules.

There is also no standard customizing option available to help you prevent defaulting to 'C' when TM is active.

Please note that using unreleased APIs in PCE is prohibited by SAP policy and fails mandatory ATC checks. The current default system design expects a TU for goods issue when TM is active.

This is what I suggest you do:

  • There is currently no known information if SAP intents to the BAdI for cloud environments. Therefore, I suggest you consider raising an SAP incident explaining the critical blocking issue and request either:
  • A Release of the relevant BAdI, or an alternative Clean Core‚Äëcompliant solution.
  • Review your TM‚ÄëEWM configuration to ensure TU creation is triggered early enough to avoid the block from happening.
  • You can also consider side‚Äëby‚Äëside enhancements via SAP BTP for non‚Äëinvasive process handling.

At present, this approach is the only way i think you could resolve the issue while remaining fully SAP‚Äëcompliant.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: o Add New Service Call Type in SAP FSM Connected to S...
entry.content:
Hello @Simon_Lehnert 

When FSM is connected to S/4HANA Public Cloud, Service Call Types are derived from Service Order Types in S/4HANA and cannot be created directly within FSM.

Possible solution steps are below

  1. Go to Manage Your Solution -Configure Your Solution.
  2. Application Area: Service Management.
  3. Use SSCUI 103751 (Define Service Order Types) to create the new type.
  4. Save and activate.
  5. Run Master Data Synchronisation in FSM to pull the new type across.

SAP Useful Reference below

  • Service Order Types ‚Äì S/4HANA Cloud Help
  • FSM Service Call Settings

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: How to fetch fields from multiple successfactor odata...
entry.content:
Hello @yashsap1 

For your requirement to extract ~133 fields across 20 SuccessFactors EC entity sets in a single iFlow, the most efficient approach is to use the Compound Employee (SFAPI) interface instead of making multiple OData GET calls.

When an Employee is Compounded

  • Returns a single, consolidated XML payload covering PerPerson, PerPersonal, EmpJob, Position, PerNationalId, email, and more.
  • Supports full or delta mode, reducing processing time and API calls.
  • Natively supported by the CPI SuccessFactors (SFAPI) adapter.
  • Simplifies mapping since all required segments are delivered together, avoiding $expand or $batch limitations in OData.

Suggested next steps:

  1. Enable and test the Compound Employee API in your SuccessFactors provisioning.
  2. Configure CPI to consume CE data via the SFAPI adapter.
  3. Map the XML segments to your target 133-field layout and deliver via SFTP.

Best regards,
Chuma

 

  • GenAI Assists contents
  • SAP Useful references
  • Introduction to the CompoundEmployee API-SAP Help

entry.title: Re: To set up a destination in SAP BTP for connecting to...
entry.content:
Hello @soujanya_vanteru_ 

For your requirement to connect SAP BTP to Microsoft Graph API for sending emails via Azure, please find the verified configuration steps below. This setup has been tested to work with the Client Credentials OAuth 2.0 flow.

1. Azure AD Configuration

Register an application in Azure AD.

Assign Application permission Mail.Send (and Mail.Send.Shared if needed).

Grant Admin Consent for these permissions.

2. SAP BTP Destination Configuration
In your BTP subaccount:

Name: AzureMailService

Type: HTTP

URL: https://graph.microsoft.com/v1.0

ProxyType: Internet

Authentication: OAuth2ClientCredentials

tokenServiceURL: https://login.microsoftonline.com/<tenant-id>/oauth2/v2.0/token

clientId: <your-client-id>

clientSecret: <your-client-secret>

scope: https://graph.microsoft.com/.default

tokenServiceURLType: Dedicated

3. Sending Emails
With Application permissions, use:

POST /v1.0/users/{senderUPN}/sendMail

Where {senderUPN} is the mailbox you are authorized to send from.

Example payload:

{
"message": {
"subject": "Test from SAP BTP",
"body": { "contentType": "HTML", "content": "<p>Hello!</p>" },
"toRecipients": [{ "emailAddress": { "address": "recipient@domain.com" } }]
},
"saveToSentItems": true
}

4. Programmatic Access (Node.js/CAP)

import { executeHttpRequest } from '@sap-cloud-sdk/http-client';
import { retrieveJwt } from '@sap-cloud-sdk/connectivity';

srv.on('sendmail', async (req) => {
const jwt = retrieveJwt(req);
const payload = { /* see JSON above */ };
await executeHttpRequest(
{ destinationName: 'AzureMailService', jwt },
{ method: 'POST', url: '/users/sender@domain.com/sendMail', data: payload }
);
});

5. Testing
Note: ‚ÄúCheck Connection‚Äù in Destinations only verifies reachability. Test with a real Graph call (e.g., GET /v1.0/$metadata) to confirm token issuance and permissions.

Best regards,

Chuma

  • GenAI Assist content
  • Reference:

Microsoft Graph API ‚Äì Send Mail

SAP BTP Destination Service ‚Äì OAuth2 Client Credentials

entry.title: Re: Attribute Transformations with SAP Integrated Busines...
entry.content:
Hi @SaiKiran9 

Thank you for walking me through your setup and providing the screenshots which provided a good detail on what the case might be. Based on those details, here is what I think might be causing the problem you are facing:

The defined time profile tied to your new planning level might not include all the PERIODID attributes you expect especially if daily or offset levels are missing.

Please note, in IBP, the Attribute Transformation framework only shows PERIODIDs that are available in the active time profile which is used by both the base and the target planning levels.

If there is any mismatch between the time profile levels of ZDAYPRODCUST and ZDAYPRODCUSTNEW, that could be the reason why you are not seeing the transformations you need. I suggest you carry out the following:

Ensure that both planning levels are linked to the same, or at least compatible time profiles. The profiles should include all relevant levels such as Day, Technical Week, Week, Month, Quarter, Year.

Make sure all the PERIODID attributes you need are active and available in your time profile configuration.

After confirming the time profiles line up between source and target, then make sure to re-try the Attribute Transformation setup and see if the full list of PERIODIDs appears.

If you‚Äôre still hitting a wall, consider creating a dedicated time profile for your transformation process that contains every intermediate level, and link it to both planning levels.

Once you have concluded these steps, i advice to try building your Attribute Transformation key figure again. With the right time profiles, you should see the complete set of PERIODID options.

I hope this helps you solve the issue. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

Creating a Key Figure

Performing Attribute Transformations

entry.title: Re: SAP ERP, Private Edition, Transition Option: What Does it Mean for You as a Healthcare Customer?
entry.content:
Challenges in this ECO system:

  • High initial cost & ROI uncertainty ‚Äì Many healthcare providers, especially smaller hospitals, hesitate due to large upfront investment with unclear short-term returns.

  • Complex customisation needs ‚Äì Healthcare processes are often unique, requiring heavy system tailoring, which increases project time and risk.

  • Integration with legacy systems ‚Äì Many hospitals still rely on older EMR, LIS, and billing systems, making smooth integration a technical and operational hurdle.

  • Change management & user adoption ‚Äì Hospital staff may resist switching from familiar tools to SAP, especially under tight schedules.

  • Regulatory & localisation challenges ‚Äì Ensuring the system meets healthcare-specific legal, insurance, and data standards in different regions can delay implementation.

  • Limited peer references ‚Äì With fewer live healthcare case studies, it‚Äôs harder for new adopters to benchmark best practices or learn from proven implementations.

In short, while SAP ERP Private Edition Transition Option offers a longer runway and stability, the healthcare sector still needs stronger training networks, more localised support, and proven adoption roadmaps to make the transition smoother.

entry.title: Re: How to change existing hierarchy in PRODHS fields acc...
entry.content:
Hello @markus_rietmann3 

SAP Note 1070939 recommends naming the initial three PRODHS fields as PRODH1‚Äì3 (without the ZZ prefix) to ensure compatibility with standard programs. However, renaming these now would disrupt dozens of generated SD condition tables, so making a direct change isn‚Äôt feasible.

If the only concern is the ABAP test class, a safer method is to create a small mapping structure with PRODH1‚Äì3 populated from your ZZ fields. Use it where the standard expects the original names. Most customers in this situation keep the ZZ fields as they are and only create mappings when necessary.

Let me know if it works

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Understanding ABAP Pipeline Engine used for Data Integration in Datasphere
entry.content:
@Martin_Kuma , Thank you for your input.
To clarify, I‚Äôm referring to an SAP S/4HANA On-Premise system in this context. As I mentioned in my previous comment, in our case we are using SDI (Smart Data Integration) via DP Agent and Using Remote Table for Real Time Replications from S4 Hana to Datasphere. When I mention Buffer Table, I specifically mean the RDB (Resilient Data Buffer).

So I don‚Äôt fully agree with your  statement that *ODQDATA, *_C, _F are the buffer tables where the logging tables post to. Remote tables cannot use ODQ, only if wrapped into CDS with CDC. 

Subscriber Logging Tables  post to the RDB as well, not just ODQDATA or its related tables.
RDB, which serves as the actual buffer in many scenarios (example Replication flow &  Data Flow in SAP Datasphere) .

entry.title: Re: SAP AVC Need to update the Bom qnty based on characte...
entry.content:
Hello @ankit_1662 

To update a BOM component‚Äôs quantity in AVC based on a characteristic:

Put the dependency rule directly on the BOM item.

Use a numeric characteristic (AVC_ANCHO) with the same unit as the BOM component.

Example AVC rule:

  • QUANTITY = quantity( AVC_ANCHO - 0.03, 'M' )
  • For classic LO-VC:
  • $SELF.QUANTITY = ( AVC_ANCHO - 0.03 )

Ensure the production version uses this BOM, and the characteristic is unit-compatible.

Describing the Advanced Variant Configuration (AVC Product Configuration)-SAP Learning 

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Story Report with Direct Reports AND Salary with Acti...
entry.content:
Hello @carlyhilder71 

The multiplication happens because the acting-pay row is duplicated for every direct report. When your Salary with Acting Pay is calculated using SUM, it ends up counting the same acting pay multiple times.

Data are aggregated per employee prior to grouping by rows in the cross tab.

  1. Create two Restricted Measures (or calculated columns in the model):
  • Annual Salary (pay comp = base)
  • Annual Acting Pay (pay comp = acting)

For each measure set:

  • Aggregation: Sum
  • Exception Aggregation: Sum
  • Exception Aggregation Dimension: Employee (Employee ID)
      1. Calculated measure:
        Salary with Acting Pay = Annual Salary + Annual Acting Pay
        Give it the same Exception Aggregation (by Employee).
        2. For direct reports, apply 'Count Distinct' to (Direct Report User ID) filtered by employee class = employee. Do not add 'Direct Report' as a row dimension; show it only as a measure.

With regards

Chuma

entry.title: Re: Help me for c_ts452 question
entry.content:
A document parking can be used:

Account assignment information is missing for a purchase order item
Account assignment information is missing for an invoice item.

Why not the others?

  • EDI invoice containing variances. This usually triggers an error or holds for invoice verification, not parking.

  • Goods receipt posted for an item needing quality inspection ‚Üí This is handled via the QM (Quality Management) process, not by parking a document.

So, the correct answers are:
2 and 3.

entry.title: Re: Handling Late Variant Configuration Changes in Assemb...
entry.content:
Below are some of the reasons why Networks and MRP don‚Äôt update on late Configuration changes

1. Network Creation Is a One-Time Event

When you change the configurable material in the sales order before the network is created, SAP deletes the old network and calls CN08 to generate a new one. Once that network has at least one operation scheduled or confirmed, or MRP has run and created dependent requirements, SAP treats it as ‚Äúin flight‚Äù and skips any subsequent regeneration logic.

2. MRP Doesn‚Äôt Retroactively Re-explode BOMs

MRP uses the planning‚Äêfile entry and the ‚Äúexplode BOM‚Äù flag to decide whether to re-explode components for existing planned orders. By default, that flag is not set for already-generated requirements, so changes to the BOM in the sales order aren‚Äôt picked up on the next MD02 run (even in planning mode 1).

In order to overcome from handling late Configuration changes, below are some options that you can explore

Option 1: Manual Delete-and-Recreate

  • Delete the existing network assignment in CN08 for the sales‚Äêorder item.
  • Change the configuration or BOM in the sales order.
  • Re-run ‚ÄúCreate Network‚Äù in CN08 (or save the order to trigger automatic regeneration).
  • Re-execute MRP (MD02) with ‚Äúadapt planning data‚Äù so the BOM is re-exploded.

Option 2: Custom Re-Generation Enhancement

Implement a user-exit or BAdI in the SD‚ÄìPS assembly integration that:

  • Detects a configuration change on save (e.g., MV45AFZZ or /SAPAPO/IF_SD_ASSEMBLY).
  • Deletes the old network (BAPI_PROJECT_NETWORK_DELETE).
  • Calls the network‚Äêcreation logic again (BAPI_PROJECT_NETWORK_CREATE) before save completion.
  • Optionally flags the planning file entry so MRP re-explodes the new BOM.


Below are some Best Practices and Recommendations

  • Aim to lock down the configuration and BOM before the network is scheduled or MRP is run.
  • For products with frequent late changes, consider using process orders instead of SD‚ÜíPS assembly networks, since process orders support standard reconfiguration transactions (CU50).
  • If you do implement a custom enhancement, ensure rigorous testing around partial confirmations and existing purchase requisitions to avoid inconsistent demand.
  • Train planners and order entry teams to handle reconfigurations via the documented delete-and-recreate process so that all steps (network, MRP, confirmations) stay in sync.

entry.title: What is SAP Build Code?
entry.content:
What is SAP Build Code?

SAP Build Code is a low-code/no-code development tool within the SAP Build suite, designed to enable business users and developers to create and customize applications with minimal coding effort.

SAP Build Code will enable rapid development and has all the features we require to build a full stack solution powered with generative AI, including pre-configured runtime and design time capabilities, enabling shorter lead time to market.

It will enable rapid development and has all the features we require to build a full stack solution powered with generative AI, including pre-configured runtime and design time capabilities, enabling shorter lead time to market.

In utilising generative AI, SAP Build Code offers businesses easier integration capabilities and a streamlined developer experience for cloud application development boosting overall productivity and driving tangible value.

Key Features of SAP Build Code:

1. Visual Development Environment: Users can create applications using a visual interface, making it easier to design user interfaces, data models, and business logic without deep coding knowledge.

2. Integration with SAP Services: SAP Build Code seamlessly integrates with various SAP services, such as SAP S/4HANA, SAP HANA Cloud, and SAP BTP, allowing users to build applications that interact with SAP data and processes.                                                                           

3.Al Assistance: Tools like SAP Joule provide Al-driven recommendations and automation to help users create data models, business logic, and UI components efficiently.                                 

4.Reusable Components: The platform offers a library of pre-built components and templates that can be reused across different projects, speeding up the development process.                       

5.Collaboration and Governance: SAP Build Code supports collaboration between different team members and provides governance features to ensure compliance with organizational standards.

6. Deployment to SAP BTP: Applications developed using SAP Build Code can be easily deployed to the SAP Business Technology Platform, ensuring scalability, security, and integration with other SAP services.

SAP Build Code includes SAP Business Application Studio, SAP Cloud Application Programming Model, SAPUI5, SAP Fiori Elements, and SAP Mobile Services.

SAP Build Code provides AI code generation with Joule copilot, and is a turn-key developer environment for coding, testing, integrations, and application lifecycle management. For more information and to get started and activate SAP Build Code in SAP BTP Trial, check out useful short tutorial on how to set up SAP Build Code on SAP BTP Trial and learning Journey 

Thank you

entry.title: Re: ITALY CU Withholding tax vendor form by e-mail
entry.content:
Oh ok. In the Public Edition, simply defining your certificate output in DT_RECEIVER, DT_CHANNEL, and DT_EMAIL_SETTINGS only tells the system what to send and to whom. You still need to wire together:

  • The PPF output action for your Withholding Tax Declaration
  • A valid vendor e-mail address in the Business Partner master
  • An outbound SMTP communication arrangement and scheduled PPF-send job
  • Without all three, your Adobe form will be generated, but it never makes it into a mail queue for delivery.

So what you can do is verify and enhance your BRF+ Output Configuration in the Manage Output Types for Withholding Tax Declaration Fiori app:

Ensure your output type (e.g. CUI_CERT) has

  • Medium = External Send (E-Mail)
  • Partner Determination = VN (Vendor)
  • Save and activate the configuration.

In the Manage Output Parameter Determination app:

  • DT_RECEIVER: Add an entry for Receiver Type = BusinessPartner, Receiver ID = ‚ÄπVendor BP‚Ä∫, Role = Supplier.
  • DT_CHANNEL: Maintain a single row where Channel = EMAIL.
  • DT_EMAIL_SETTINGS: Define your sender address, subject text, and body template.

Check Vendor‚Äôs E-Mail contact by launching Manage Business Partner and display the vendor (BP role = Supplier). Go to Contact Persons ‚Üí select the contact and click Communication. Ensure there is:

  • Communication Method = 0005 (E-Mail)
  • A valid E-Mail address in the ‚ÄúE-Mail‚Äù field
  • ‚ÄúDefault‚Äù flag set so the system picks it up automatically

If this isn‚Äôt maintained, the PPF action has no recipient and silently skips sending.

Configure Outbound E-Mail Communication because SCOT is not exposed in Public Cloud, you must use the built-in Communication Arrangement:

  • Open Communication Systems and verify your SMTP host/system is defined and trusted.
  • In Communication Arrangements, locate the scenario Default Outbound Email (often called EMAIL_OUTBOUND).
  • Edit the arrangement to:
    • Point to your SMTP server (host, port, credentials if needed)
    • Define a default sender domain/address

Save and activate the arrangement. This replaces the on-premise SCOT node setup and tells SAP where to push outbound mails.

Next what you have to do is Schedule and Monitor the PPF Send Job. By default in cloud, email‚Äêtriggering PPF actions are placed in a staging table and sent by a background job:

  • Go to View Job Schedules ‚Üí Create Job.
  • Select Program: /SAPAPO/OUTPUT_CONTROLLER_SEND (or the equivalent cloud-version PPF send program).
  • Schedule it to run every few minutes.
  • Use Monitor Output (or Business Communications app) to check that your withholding-tax messages move from ‚ÄúReady to Send‚Äù to ‚ÄúSent.‚Äù


If your PPF send job never fires, no mail ever leaves the system.

entry.title: Re: MB5B Report: Opening Stock (Tables) to be used
entry.content:
There is no single ‚Äúopening-stock‚Äù table in SAP MM. If your system has update group 001 active on MSEG, SAP populates the S031 info-structure daily with opening, receipts, issues, and closing stock per material/plant/storage location.

Key fields in Table S031 are MANDT, WERKS, LGORT, MATNR, BUDAT (posting date), SOBEG (opening stock), SBEAR (receipts), SENDER (issues), SEND (closing stock)

Pros

  • Instant read of daily openings/closes
  • Very fast for high data volumes

Cons

  • Only works if update group 001 is active and S031 is up-to-date
  • Doesn‚Äôt include special-stock segments unless you‚Äôve enhanced S031


When S031 isn‚Äôt available or you need real-time accuracy, calculate opening stock by combining:

MARD: Current unrestricted stock at plant/storage location

  • LABST (unrestricted), INSME (in quality), SPEME (blocked)

MSEG + MKPF: All goods movements up to your target date

  • Filter MSEG by MKPF‚ÄìBUDAT < your posting date
  • Movement qty in base unit: MSEG‚ÄìMENGE

(Optionally) MBEW if you need valuation

  • Use MBEW‚ÄìBWTAR (valuation type), BWTAR‚ÄìSTPRS (standard price)

The calculation logic should be

  • Pull current stock from MARD
  • Subtract all day‚Äôs postings (BUDAT = posting date) from that to arrive at opening
  • Group by material, plant, storage location

Pros

  • Always up-to-date
  • Handles any stock segment you code for

Cons

  • More expensive on database
  • Must handle unit conversions, special stocks, etc., exactly as MB5B does

If you prefer not to build SQL logic, SAP supplies function modules that encapsulate MB5B logic:

  • MB_STOCKS_FOR_POSTING_DATE (often called by MB5B itself)
  • MB_GET_STOCKS_ON_POSTING_DATE

The FM returns a table (lt_stocks) with opening, receipts, issues, and closing stocks per material.

entry.title: Re: Incorrect Pricing Condition Assigned During EDI Sales...
entry.content:
When you create an inbound ORDERS IDoc via the SAP_COM_0223 C4C‚Äêto-S/4HANA communication arrangement, the system still runs its standard pricing determination exactly as if you‚Äôd typed the order in manually. In your case:

  • ZPR0 is defined in your pricing procedure as the ‚Äúcorrect‚Äù base-price condition for EDI
  • ZPS0 is also in your procedure (typically as the intercompany price)

Because of the way your access sequence and condition records are set up, the system never finds a valid ZPR0 record for your customer-material-plant combination and simply continues down the search sequence until it locates a ZPS0 record.

Confirm Which Pricing Procedure and Access Sequence are in Play. This you can do by running a pricing trace on the order in Fiori (e.g. ‚ÄúTrace Pricing Determination‚Äù) or display the order and, in the Item ‚Üí Conditions tab, click Analysis.
You‚Äôll see exactly which access steps (condition tables) were hit and why ZPR0 failed (no record) and ZPS0 succeeded.

Check and maintain your ZPR0 Condition Records by going to VK13 to verify that you actually have a valid ZPR0 record for that combination of sales org / dist. channel / customer / material / plant. ‚Äì If no record exists, create one in VK11. As soon as a ZPR0 record is found, the access sequence will pick it up first (assuming it‚Äôs higher in the sequence than ZPS0

  • Review your Access Sequence Configuration in SPRO (or the equivalent Fiori apps), go to Sales and Distribution ‚Üí Basic Functions ‚Üí Pricing ‚Üí Access Sequences ‚Üí ‚ÄúDefine Access Sequences.‚Äù
  • Find the access sequence used by your base‚Äêprice condition type.
  • Ensure the condition table for ZPR0 sits above the table for ZPS0 ‚Äî and that the Exclusive flag is set so the search stops once a ZPR0 record is found.

Finally, validate Pricing Procedure assignment for EDI Orders. Even though the inbound IDoc uses standard order type ORDERS, double-check:

Sales Document Type (OVKK/VOV8): Verify the pricing procedure assigned to the EDI order type hasn‚Äôt been altered to point to an intercompany-only procedure.
Customer-Pricing Procedure Determination: Confirm your customer classification ‚Üí pricing procedure mapping doesn‚Äôt default to an ‚Äúintercompany‚Äù procedure under certain customer groups.

If a separate pricing procedure is being determined (one that lists ZPS0 as the first base price), you‚Äôll need to adjust that determination rule so the same procedure with ZPR0 is used instead.

entry.title: Case Management: Configuring the Input Step in the Case Flow
entry.content:
Input step in guided case flow is designed to render the configured fields directly within the flow, allowing agents to update them without navigating away from the guided process. This avoids the need to search for fields in the case details screen or make multiple clicks to reach them, thereby enabling faster and more efficient case handling.

Prerequisites:

Draft case type version

Configuration:

1. Open DRAFT case type version in detail view.

2. Navigate to Case Flow tab.

3. Click on Create Step button which shows the list of step types that can be created.

4. Click on Input step type from the list which open up a main view in a seperate tab.

5. Enter the mandatory field name, optionally provide the display ID, help text and mandatory step flag. If mandatory flag is set, the phase can be completed only when the step is completed. 

 6. Optionally, create preconditions for the Input step. If set, the fields in the form become editable, and the step can be completed only when these preconditions are met. To create pre-conditions, click on Create Pre-conditions button.

 7. Set the pre-conditions and click on Save.

 8. Newly created pre-conditions will appear in the Pre-conditions section of the right panel. Edit and delete options are available for the pre-condition. Click the respective button to perform the action.

 9. Add all the relevant fields. You can either click the plus (+) button to pull the field into the middle panel as a new row, or drag and drop it into the desired row. A maximum of three fields can be added to a row, and any excess fields will be placed in the next row.

 10. Click on Save to create the Input step.

 11. Close the Input step tab and navigate to Case Template tab. The newly created Input step will be added as the last step in the phase.

 12. Optionally, rearrange the step using the drag handle.

13. Edit and delete options are available for the step. Click the respective button to perform the action.

14. Finally, click on Activate button to activate the case type version.

 This completes the Input step configuration.

Input Step in action:

1. Create a case with the newly activated case type, and open it in detail view. Enter values for all form fields, then click Save to apply the changes.

 2. Click on Set Step to Done button to complete the step.

Summary:

In summary, the Input step streamlines case handling by placing essential fields directly within the guided case flow. By reducing navigation and clicks, it empowers agents to work more quickly and efficiently, ensuring a smoother experience for both agents and customers.

entry.title: Re: SAP Enable Now ‚Äì Different Workflows for Original and...
entry.content:
Hi @Solution_Master 

Thank you for your detailed questions. Let me walk you throug it.

Unfortunately, it is not possible to manage different workflows within a single workarea in SAP Enable Now. The system only allows you to assign one workflow per workarea. This means you cannot directly have distinct workflows for original content creation and translations within the same work area based on you object type or status. However, to enable you keep everything organized within a single project, I would suggest we look at some best practice

An option would be to use Separate Workareas for Different Workflow needs and here is your best approach:

  • Maintain your original content creation workflow in one workarea
  • Create a separate workarea dedicated to translated content, where you can assign the translation-specific workflow.
  • Although this requires switching workareas, it keeps workflows clean and tailored to the process stage.

A second option would be to leverage Object Metadata and Filters to Manage Content by

  • Using metadata tags or custom properties to distinguish original versus translated content.
  • This will help you in managing, filtering, and reporting within each workarea, so users are guided on which content belongs to which process.

Another option would be to automate Content Movement Between Workareas:

  • Automate the duplication or import of your original content into the desired translation workarea using SAP Enable Now‚Äôs APIs or scheduled tasks. This will ensure streamlining your work.
  • This way, translators always work on the correct copy linked to the translation workflow without manual intervention.

You can also consider Workflow Extensions or Customizations:

  • Please note that while the out-of-the-box Enable Now only supports one workflow per workarea, check if your environment supports workflow extensions or custom scripting that could change workflow behaviour based on object attributes.
  • This is often limited and depends on your system version and support status.

Finally, you have the option to coordinate Publishing and Version Management:

  • Considering your original workflow automates publishing, make sure the translated content publishing is coordinated separately to avoid conflicts or overwriting.

To summarize, the current design expects one workflow per workarea. To manage multiple workflows in the same project, best practice is to split original and translation content into separate workareas, each with appropriate workflows, while using metadata and automation to keep the content aligned.

If you haven‚Äôt already, I recommend reaching out to SAP Enable Now support for further guidance.

I hope this provides some clarity. I am happy to help if you have further questions.

If you find my response helpful, kindly accept the answer and award a Kudos to this post. Your support is appreciated.

Best regards

Chris

entry.title: Re: How to declare both quantity and billing percentage i...
entry.content:
Milestone Billing and Progress Billing are mutually exclusive.  If the client wants to bill a % of the total contract based on a milestone achievement then how does the actual quantity fit into the amount to be billed?  A typical ECO company will bill using Progress Billing rather than Milestone Billing.  For Progress Billing you list the Schedule of Values on the Sales Order and every month invoice for a partial quantity that was achieved during the month.  The unit of measure on each Sales Order Line Item can be different, for example, for Cement you can use Tons, then for Site Clearing you can use %.  

Hope this helps.

entry.title: SAP RISE - Six Integration Patterns You‚Äôll Face
entry.content:
In one of my previous blogs Why SAP ISA-M Still Matters ‚Äì A Strategic Foundation for Modern Integration I have given some insights in which project& situations I am currently using ISA-M do define my Integration patterns.  What should be more strategic then RISE nowadays?  

 

üß≠ The Integration Architect‚Äôs Dilemma in RISE Projects

It usually starts with excitement ‚Äî ‚ÄúWe‚Äôre moving to RISE!‚Äù. But as the Integration Architect, you feel a shift in the room once you ask:

‚ÄúHow will your business-critical integrations survive the move?‚Äù

‚ÄúHow will our Integration Patterns change in a Private Cloud Environment?‚Äù

‚ÄúDo we have to an option to be part of this modernization?‚Äù

In too many RISE conversations, integration is not part the initial  ‚Äî and yet, but everything depends on it. Whether you‚Äôre facing direct system-to-system integrations, legacy SAP PO platforms, or the modernization path toward Integration Suite and AEM: you need clarity.

 

Let‚Äôs talk about the 6 most common integration scenarios I encounter in RISE projects ‚Äî and let‚Äôs do a deep dive in one of them.

üìåContext: What Makes RISE Integration Different?

ISA-M allows us to talk in Integration patterns ‚Äî proven, repeatable ways to connect cloud, on-prem, and hybrid landscapes.

Draw your Integration landscape abstract as below and repeat the same for all Integration Domains and Integration Patterns, maybe event styles. We focus on the typical Process Integration patterns which often are.

üîç Scenario 1: On-Premise to On-Premise (e.g., existing ECC system ‚Üí S/4, within same on-prem datacenter)

üí¨ Comment:
This is often the existing baseline. When the customers still host their systems locally. No RISE adaption in this case

üîç Scenario 2: Private Cloud to Private Cloud (e.g., S/4 to S/4 Integration, within same RISE datacenter)

 

üîßTechnology in use:

  • SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell on a Private Cloud hyperscaler, such as Azure or AWS
  • VPN or direct peering within same hyperscaler
  • Azure VNet Peering, AWS VPC Peering, or similar as secure tunnel
  • Usage of transactions and APIM Management operations

üîç Scenario 3: Private Cloud to Public Cloud (RISE workload connects to SaaS like SuccessFactors)

üí¨ Comment:

For hybrid Integration SAP Integration Suite could be used as natural entry point

üîç Scenario 4: Public Cloud to Public Cloud (e.g., SuccessFactors ‚Üî Ariba or Salesforce ‚Üî S/4 in RISE)

üí¨ Comment:
This is a modernization sweet spot. Cloud-native to cloud-native with no concrete RISE touchpoints.

üîç Scenario 5: On-Premise to Public Cloud

üí¨ Comment:
This is often the existing baseline. When the customers still host their backend systems locally but use SaaS applications for certain LoBs. No RISE adaption in this case

üîç Scenario 6: On-Premise to Private Cloud (e.g., ECC ‚Üí RISE in Azure, hybrid operation)

üí¨ Comment:
This hybrid pattern is very common in staged RISE transitions. Customers keep some systems on-prem while moving others (‚Äúearly adaptors) into RISE.

 

üîßModernization Reality Check

Most customers do one of three things:

  1. Move PO Interfaces to SAP Integration Suite, Cloud Integration  and SAP Integration Suite, Edge Cell  
  2. Modernize to SAP Advanced Event Mesh
  3. Use more featreus of the SAP Integration Suite, such as API Managmenet

So here‚Äôs what I recommend to every architect:

  • Audit your interface and integration technologies before RISE.
  • Classify interfaces using along the patterns in this blog.
  • Decide per pattern: Keep, Modernize, or Sunset.
  • Actively design your new integration landscape ‚Äî don‚Äôt wait for someone else to.

 

üìû Let‚Äôs Build Smarter RISE Integrations

I‚Äôve worked on numerous RISE integration journeys and built a reference architecture library covering each scenario. If you want to see the diagrams, dig into patterns, or compare your setup ‚Äî I‚Äôm happy to help.

Ping us on SAP Integration Modernization <integration.modernization@sap.com>

entry.title: Display item of content page on master page in SAP S/4HANA Public Cloud
entry.content:
Displaying a Text Field/Value from the Content Form on the Master Page in Adobe Forms.
Sometimes it can be tricky to display a field from the content page on the master page in Adobe Forms, because the master page does not contain any XML structure in the Data View (except for elements like the logo and footer). The master page does not have direct access to invoice, billing, or other master data.

Assumption: You have already created both a master form template and a content form template according to your business needs.

In this example, I have created:

  • Content form template: YY1_CINV_BILL_BE

  • Master form template: YY1_INVOICE_MASTER_FORM

Scenario

We need to print the invoice number on the master form template (instead of the content form template) because the requirement is to show the invoice number on every page of the PDF output.


Step 1: Download the templates

Download both the content form template and the master form template. After downloading, extract the XDP files and open the master form template in Adobe LiveCycle Designer.

You will notice that the DataConnection Node does not contain the invoice number, because it is part of the content form data. 

 

Now open the content form in Adobe LiveCycle Designer. Here, you can see that the invoice number is available in the content form ‚Äî but our requirement is to also display it on the master form.

Step 2: Bind the invoice number in the content form
Add a Text Field (name it InvoiceNumber) on the content form and bind it to the correct XML node for the invoice number.

Step 3: Create a hidden subform: 

If you want the invoice number to appear only on the master page and not on the content page, create a hidden subform.

  • Set the subform‚Äôs visibility to hidden.

  • Drag the InvoiceNumber text field into this hidden subform.

If you also want the invoice number on the content form, you can skip creating the hidden subform.

Step 4: Add the text field in the master form

Open the master form template in Adobe LiveCycle Designer and add a Text Field (also named InvoiceNumber).

In this example, I have added the field to both mst1 and mst2, since the invoice number must appear on both master pages.

Step 5: Write JavaScript to access content form data
Select the textField of the Master Form Template and then write one Javascript code in order to access the data of content form. The Javscript code is written in the Initialize event of the InvoiceNumber textField.

The path (Form.HeaderSubform.HiddenSubform.InvoiceNumber.rawValue) comes from inspecting the content form structure. We simply reference the rawValue of that node.

Step 6: Upload and test

Once the changes are complete in both the content form and the master form:

  1. Save the forms.

  2. Upload them to the public cloud using the Maintain Form Templates app.

 



Finally, test your invoice PDF using the Manage Invoicing Document app. You will now be able to see the invoice number printed on the left side of every master page.
Please let me know if you have any other solution for this requirement.
Happy Learning !!


Thanks,
Shubham

entry.title: #SITCWB2024 üé§ Digital Supply Chain Planning - Como integrar a estrat√©gia a opera√ß√£o
entry.content:
Bio do palestrante

Paulo Fernandes √© Diretor da SCM‚ÄëDesign Consulting, empresa especializada em supply chain e demand‚Äëdriven planning, com atua√ß√£o destacada em SAP APO, IBP e tecnologias digitais para planejamento. Atua na defini√ß√£o e implanta√ß√£o de solu√ß√µes que promovem transforma√ß√£o na cadeia de abastecimento no Brasil e exterior

 

Descri√ß√£o da palestra

Paulo aborda os desafios contempor√¢neos na cadeia de abastecimento como velocidade, inova√ß√£o, produtividade, e valor agregado‚Äîe mostra como super√°-los por meio da integra√ß√£o entre n√≠veis estrat√©gico, t√°tico e operacional. Explica conceitos como S&OP (Sales & Operation Planning) e S&OE (Sales & Operation Execution), destacando que planejamento efetivo √© como combinar um mapa (estrat√©gia) com um GPS (programa√ß√£o e execu√ß√£o).

Apresenta a evolu√ß√£o das solu√ß√µes SAP: desde o R/3, passando pelo APO (Advanced Planning and Optimization), at√© o IBP (Integrated Business Planning) em ambiente cloud, integrado ao S/4HANA e complementado por m√≥dulos como Ariba e SAC. Enfatiza os benef√≠cios dos m√≥dulos IBP previs√£o de demanda com machine learning, otimiza√ß√£o de estoque, sequenciamento de produ√ß√£o, e gest√£o de promessas (ATP) que juntos promovem maior efici√™ncia, produtividade do planejador e melhor uso dos ativos.

Ao final, apresenta a atua√ß√£o da SCM-Design, fundada em 2015 e com foco regional tamb√©m no Peru, oferecendo consultoria estruturada e transforma√ß√£o em ondas, de acordo com a capacidade dos clientes.

*** Todas as palestras aqui *** 

Resumo da palestra

1. Desafios do contexto atual da supply chain

Empresas precisam ser mais r√°pidas, inovadoras e produtivas, entregando valor com menos recursos e maior competitividade. Isso exige integra√ß√£o entre estrat√©gia, planejamento e execu√ß√£o.

2. Diferentes camadas decis√≥rias

  • Estrat√©gico: definir o prop√≥sito e objetivos gerais da empresa (como tra√ßar uma rota no mapa).

  • T√°tico e Operacional: planejar e programar a√ß√µes concretas (como usar o GPS para decidir a rota exata, o tempo de chegada e a sequ√™ncia das etapas).

3. Papel do planejamento

Evita retrabalho e eleva a efetividade operacional. O supply chain ideal funciona como uma corrente: qualquer oscila√ß√£o em um elo afeta todo o conjunto.

4. Evolu√ß√£o das solu√ß√µes SAP

  • R/3 (MRP/MPS): planejamento e produ√ß√£o limitados.

  • APO (in-memory): surge nos anos 2000 para suprir limita√ß√µes do RP, com melhor capacidade de planejamento e otimiza√ß√£o.

  • IBP (desde ~2014/15): plataforma cloud p√∫blica que substitui parcialmente o APO, oferece m√≥dulos modernos integrados aos processos t√°ticos e operacionais.

  • S/4HANA: integra execu√ß√£o com funcionalidades de planejamento migradas do APO (como sequenciamento e gest√£o de cotas), al√©m dos m√≥dulos complementares Ariba (colabora√ß√£o de abastecimento) e SAC (planejamento financeiro no contexto do S&OP).

5. M√≥dulos e funcionalidades do IBP

  • Demand Planning: previs√£o de vendas com intelig√™ncia artificial e machine learning.

  • IBP for Supply & Response: planejamento t√°tico e operacional com base em ordens.

  • Inventory Policy: otimiza√ß√£o de estoques considerando incertezas e localiza√ß√µes.

  • Embedded Sequencing (em S/4HANA): sequenciamento de produ√ß√£o cont√≠nuo, detalhado por dia/hora.

  • ATP (Available to Promise): gest√£o de promessas de entrega, essencial para grandes clientes.

6. Opera√ß√£o e benef√≠cios cont√≠nuos

O IBP recebe atualiza√ß√µes trimestrais sem causar instabilidade‚Äîgra√ßas ao design do sistema e ao Fiori, interface que facilita uso com dashboards e Excel, valorizando a produtividade do planejador e execu√ß√£o √°gil.

7. Resultados e ROI

Empresas que adotam IBP e m√≥dulos relacionados garantem ganhos em receita, redu√ß√£o de custos, uso mais eficiente dos ativos e aumento da produtividade dos planejadores. A transforma√ß√£o traz valor concreto.

8. Abordagem da SCM-Design Consulting

Fundada em 2015, com escrit√≥rio no Brasil e no Peru, a SCM-Design promove projetos de transforma√ß√£o em ondas, calibrando o ritmo conforme a maturidade do cliente, para garantir ado√ß√£o gradual e sustent√°vel.

 

Considera√ß√µes finais

A palestra de Paulo Fernandes apresentou uma vis√£o clara e fundamentada de como elevar o supply chain por meio da tecnologia digital e da integra√ß√£o de processos. A trajet√≥ria do R/3 ao IBP e S/4HANA mostra a evolu√ß√£o das solu√ß√µes SAP e como elas habilitam maior sofistica√ß√£o no planejamento, execu√ß√£o e valor agregado. A abordagem consultiva da SCM-Design refor√ßa a import√¢ncia de diagn√≥sticos adequados e implementa√ß√£o por etapas, para transformar capacidades e resultados com seguran√ßa e efic√°cia.

entry.title: #SITCWB2024 üé§ Abertura do SAP Inside Track Curitiba
entry.content:

Durante a fala, foi refor√ßada a import√¢ncia de os participantes criarem seu cadastro na SAP Community para acessar conte√∫do, participar de discuss√µes e acompanhar eventos. Tamb√©m foi abordado o papel dos curadores na media√ß√£o e incentivo √† participa√ß√£o.

entry.title: Re: SAP Community Escape House for August - Fiori Element with Flexible Programming Model
entry.content:
In case you are wondering why your changes are not reflected on the UI, add the following parameter in the app URL

 sap-ui-xx-viewCache=false

Depending on how you run the app, this parameter will either not be used or removed. Without it you might have many caching issues.

I really enjoyed how the rich text editor looks like a simple text in display mode. I found a bit confusing knowing which one should I use but the FPM documentation is all you need.

Congratulations for the team who managed to come up with this exercise.
